trivia: Use this only for university. For school or general skills, use lernen.
Short and sharp, like a needle prick!
Related to "Service" in a restaurant context.
A bit advanced, but common in tech jobs.
Specific to the act of teaching a class.
Sounds a bit like "Lesson" (what you read).
One of the most important verbs in German!
Like the word "Spiel" (a sales pitch or performance).
From "sprechen" (to speak). A meeting is where you speak together.
Solar + Auto. Compound words take the gender of the last word (das Auto).
Related to the mineral "beryl," once used for lenses.
Sounds like "Dish"—which you put on a table.
Zeit means time. A newspaper tells you what's happening at this time.
Think of a "Stash" you keep in your bag.
Think of the "Side" of a leaf of paper.
Related to "close" (schließen). A key closes things.
Think of "Stiff"—a pen is a stiff writing tool.
Bild (picture) + Schirm (shield). A shield for pictures!
Ends in -ion, which is almost always feminine in German.
Wörter (words) + Buch (book). A book of words.
Lippen (lips) + Stift (pen). A pen for your lips!
Sonne (sun) + Schirm (shield). Like a rain-shield, but for sun.

sentence: Peter und Lucie sind die Eltern.
trivia: Only exists in the plural form in German.

sentence: Das ist der Mann von Lucie.
Das ist Lucie, die Frau von Peter.
Felix ist der Sohn von Peter.
Sarah ist die Tochter von Lucie.
Felix ist der Bruder von Sarah.
Sarah ist die Schwester von Felix.
Susanne und Ben sind die Geschwister.
trivia: German has a single word for brothers and sisters combined.

sentence: Ben ist der Onkel von Sarah.
Susanne ist die Tante von Felix.
Er lebt jetzt allein in Köln.

trivia: Schokolade + Kuchen. Compound nouns take the gender of the last word (der Kuchen).
English cognate. Words ending in -ion are feminine.

sentence: Mein Auto hat das Kennzeichen L-ZB 6168.
Wien ist die Hauptstadt von Österreich.

trivia: Zahlen means numbers; to pay is to give the numbers!
Similar to "Read"—imagine reading out loud to talk.
Be- + suchen (to search). You seek someone out to visit them.
Anything ending in -chen is neuter and means "little." It's a "little bread."
A classic German street food: sausage with curry sauce.
Think of a "Stick" or a "Stack"—a portion of something.
Irregular verb: ich nehme, du nimmst, er nimmt.
A polite way to express a wish.
A famous Austrian/German dish. The word is the same in English.
Cognate with "Center." Words ending in -um are usually neuter.
Ends in -ung, which is always feminine in German.
The person who does the malen.
A modern career term: Daten + Analystin.
One of the few countries that always uses a feminine article.
Most countries are neuter and usually don't use the article.
Think of a "Place" on a leaderboard.
Used for a specific address or city.
Think of "tuning" an instrument to make it "right".
Look for the big red "A" symbol in Germany.
Think of a "Coffer" where you keep money to buy things.
Related to Buch (book). You record the stay in a book.
Ends in -ung, so it is always feminine.

sentence: Das Zimmer ist für eine Nacht.
Der Code steht auf der Karte.

trivia: Think of a "purse" (Börse) where money is handled.
Irregular verb: du fährst, er/sie fährt.
